Within a minute, nearly 200 people were dead, crushed by collapsing walls and ceilings. Many more were injured by broken glass and falling debris. As if the people had not already suffered enough, even more lives were lost when the four meter-high tsunami crashed in from the coastline. When the dust settled, nearly all the houses in both cities were reduced to rubble. Notably, the Panamá-Colón railway was completely derailed and will be out of service for months. While the cathedral in Ciudad Panamá has not collapsed, it is badly damaged, and cracks have formed on all of its arches.

\n\nThe first, less powerful shock occurred at 6:22 AM, causing the inhabitants of Liguria to flee their homes in a panic. By the time the immense second shock hit seven minutes later, many had foolishly returned inside. Over six hundred people lost their lives in the ensuing destruction. Not long after the second shock, the coastline was also hit by a four meter-high tsunami, leading to even more calamity. The earthquake left the town closest to the epicenter, Diano Marina, without a single intact building. In all, over twenty thousand people have become homeless. The earthquake caused minor damage even as far away as Marseille and was felt even in Basel, Montpellier and Sardinia.

\n\nPlate tectonics are arguably of greater influence to Japan than any other country. Located on the borders of the Pacific, Philippine, Amur and Okhotsk plates, Japan is extremely mountainous, meaning that most of its population is in large cities on the coast. But the very forces that formed the islands on which Japan lies also repeatedly cause it great destruction. Now, the earth has once again violently unleashed its destructive power in an earthquake, hitting the Nobi plain, where Nagoya is located, with the brunt of its force. More than seven thousand people have died, crushed by collapsing buildings or suffocated by the fires that destroyed what remained of their homes. The earthquake, which was felt throughout Japan, has caused such widespread damage that it will take many years to rebuild.

\n\nTragedy has befallen Yamagata Prefecture. At 5:35 PM today, a terrible earthquake ravaged the region, killing over seven hundred people and injuring eight thousand more. The loss of life was especially great in the city of Sakata, where the earthquake's epicenter was located. Many of the prefecture's primarily wooden houses were damaged, with nearly four thousand collapsing entirely. The disaster did not even end with the cessation of the violent shaking, as numerous fires broke out, torching many of the remaining houses. Physical changes in the shape of the terrain are observed to have occurred in several places, as cracks have formed in the ground, hills have been pushed out of the earth and depressions have sunk into it.

\n\nThe city of Nafplio in the Peloponnese has been our capital since 1827. Having a comparatively large popultion and being removed from the rest of Greece by the narrow Isthmus of Corinth, the city acted as the heart of the Greek Revolution. Now that the dust has settled, many influential voices have suggested that we relocate the capital to the ancient city of Athens. We must, however, recognize that the heart of classical Greece is not what it used to be: With its population only at about seven thousand, Athens is curently little more than a big village clustered around the Acropolis. It has no water supply network, public lighting or transport systems. Additionally, civil and social administration is currently almost non-existant. Much work will have to be done to restore the city to its former glory.

\n\nEastern Rumelia, an artificial creation of the Berlin Treaty, was established as an autonomous territory of the Ottoman Empire separate from the Principality of Bulgaria for the purpose of preventing the creation of a greater Bulgarian state. As its population is almost entirely made up of Bulgarians, many living in the province have advocated for unification, as the the people of both states are one, be they divided by a border or not. The Bulgarian Secret Central Revolutionary Committee, founded in Plovdiv, was created with the goal of toppling the Ottoman administration and achieving the unification of Bulgaria. Now, the day has finally come: Governor Gavril Krastevich has been arrested by the rebels, paraded through the streets of Plovdiv and expelled to Constantinople. We have received the temporary government's request for unification, however we must act with caution: Serbia may use our violation of the Treaty of Berlin as a pretext to declare war.

\n\nFollowing a bloodless revolution, the Ottoman administration in the autonomous province of Eastern Rumelia created by the Treaty of Berlin has been sent into exile, and the new revolutionary government has declared its unification with its northern neighbor, Bulgaria. Not only has this angered Russia, Austria and the Ottoman Empire, who all desire stability and calculable outcomes in the Balkans, it is especially worrisome for Serbs and Greeks. The Principality of Bulgaria has laid claim to all lands inhabited by Bulgarians, including in Macedonia and Thrace, areas desired by Serbia and Greece respectively. Thus, it may be best to strike while the iron is hot: Bulgaria has not had time to levy an army from the newly acquired province, and the great powers will not come to its aid. As the unification is in violation of the Berlin Treaty, we even have a justification for war. Has the time come to put the Bulgarians in their place once and for all?

\n\nDue to the recent unification of the Principality of Bulgaria and the Ottoman autonomous province of Eastern Rumelia, the Kingdom of Serbia has declared war. King Milan Obrenovic has cited numerous grievances as causes: Bulgaria has violated the Berlin Treaty, upset the balance of power and harbored Serbian agitants who went into exile following the Timok Rebellion. Additionally, Bulgarian forces expelled Serbian soldiers from a guardhouse in disputed territory created by a change in the course of the Timok River. Now, the Royal Serbian Army has crossed the border into Bulgaria to exact its punishment, retake the disputed lands and put the Bulgarians in their place. The great powers, themselves angered by Bulgaria's violation of the Berlin Treaty and its refusal to heed their counsel, have decided to remain neutral. The Serbian army, commanded personally by King Milan, has begun marching to Sofia, and only time will tell who will emerge victorious.

\n\nThe Bijagós Archipelago is a group of islands off the coast of Guinea-Bissau, consisting of 88 islands, islets and islets. Lisbon has claimed the islands for centuries, designating them a part of Portuguese Guinea. In reality, Portuguese control has always been nominal at best. In 1792, Britain attempted to build a settlement on the main island, but it had to be given up the following year due to many colonists dying of disease. This short-lived outpost is nonetheless the basis for the UK's current claim to the archipelago, which it first raised in 1834, beginning a dispute with the Portuguese that has gone on for decades. Now, the two parties have come to us, requesting that we arbitrate the issue. It is now up to America to decide the fate of the Bolama Archipelago.

\n\nAfter the surrender of H. M. de Kock's beleaguered forces, the Java War, which has gone on for over 5 years, has finally come to the close. The war began in 1825, when Prince Diponegoro used tensions caused by a government road project to begin a rebellion. A member of the Yogyakarta royal family, Prince Diponegoro's little brother was given the throne in his stead, leaving him humiliated and hostile to the Dutch administration. Though he received significant support from the Javanese people, burdened as they were by the Dutch land tax system, he was forced to avoid open battle due to the superior equipment of the Dutch, instead launching a campaign of guerrilla warfare. Now, after being caught in countless ambushes and facing massive resistance from the population, Dutch general Hendrick Merkus de Kock, commander of the Dutch forces in Java, has finally conceded. With this unprecedented Javanese victory, Prince Diponegoro has assumed the throne of the Yogyakarta Sultanate, which has now taken over the entire island of Java.

The war began in 1825, when Prince Diponegoro used tensions caused by a government road project to begin a rebellion. Though he received significant support from the Javanese people, burdened as they were by the Dutch land tax system, he was forced to avoid open battle due to the superior equipment of the Dutch, instead launching a campaign of guerrilla warfare. The rebel forces were gradually wittled down in each skirmish they engaged, eventually reducing them to just Prince Diponegoro himself and several dozen of his most loyal followers. Recognizing the futility of his situation, he has handed himself over to Dutch general de Kock, ending the revolt for good. The Prince will be sent into exile on the island of Sulawesi.

The war began in 1825, when Prince Diponegoro used tensions caused by a government road project to begin a rebellion. A member of the Yogyakarta royal family, Prince Diponegoro's little brother was given the throne in his stead, leaving him humiliated and hostile to the Dutch administration. Though he received significant support from the Javanese people, burdened as they were by the Dutch land tax system, he was forced to avoid open battle due to the superior equipment of the Dutch, instead launching a campaign of guerrilla warfare. The rebel forces were gradually wittled down in each skirmish they engaged, eventually reducing them to just Prince Diponegoro himself and several dozen of his most loyal followers. Recognizing the futility of his situation, he has handed himself over to Dutch general de Kock, ending the revolt for good. The Prince will be sent into exile on the island of Sulawesi.

\n\nThe Malay Peninsula has been home to several sultanates for many centuries, including Pahang, Perak, Selangor and Johor. With the world firmly having entered the age of imperialism, many nearby regions have been colonized, leaving the small, weak and disorganized sultanates vulnerable. We can leverage our influence in the area to persuade the sultans to form a federation under our protection, leaving the individual sultans as monarchs of their respective realms. This would increase our authority over the peninsula and make its administration more efficient. We should also take into consideration whether to add other ethnically Malay regions to the federation, such as those on the islands of Borneo and Sumatra. A union of all Malays under our control would be more powerful, it may also present more of a challenge to keep under our control.
